title: 8 Tax Benefits Every Fix-and-Flip Investor Should Know
excerpt: Maximize your profits on every flip by understanding the key tax advantages available to real estate investors. Learn how depreciation, deductions, and smart reinvestment strategies can help you keep more of your hard-earned money.

content.text: Fix-and-flip projects can be highly profitable, but taxes can eat into your returns if you’re not prepared. By leveraging the right tax benefits, you can reduce your tax liability and boost your bottom line. Here are eight tax strategies every fix-and-flip investor should know.

While depreciation is most commonly used for rental properties, if you hold a property as a rental before flipping, you can deduct the property’s declining value over time. This reduces your taxable income. If you later sell, be aware of depreciation recapture, but you may be able to minimize it through a 1031 exchange or by converting the property to your primary residence.

items: Travel costs related to managing your flips

content.text: While capital improvements must be depreciated, many day-to-day expenses related to your fix-and-flip business are fully deductible. Track every expense to maximize your deductions.

If you reinvest profits from a flip into another investment property, a 1031 exchange lets you defer capital gains taxes. You must follow strict IRS timelines: identify the new property within 45 days and close within 180 days.
Investing your gains in designated Opportunity Zones can defer or even reduce your capital gains taxes. Hold your investment for 5, 7, or 10 years to unlock additional tax breaks.

If you operate your fix-and-flip business as an LLC, S-Corp, or partnership, you may be eligible for a 20% deduction on qualified business income through the pass-through deduction (currently available through 2025).
Short-term flips (held less than a year) are taxed as ordinary income, which can be as high as 37%. Hold properties for more than a year to benefit from long-term capital gains rates (0%–20%).
Consider using self-directed IRAs or solo 401(k)s to invest in real estate. These accounts let you grow your investments tax-deferred or tax-free, depending on the account type.
Rental income isn’t subject to FICA (payroll) taxes, unlike earned income. If you hold properties as rentals before flipping, this can be an additional tax savings.

By understanding and applying these tax benefits, fix-and-flip investors can keep more profits and grow their business faster. Always consult with a qualified tax professional to ensure you’re taking full advantage of available deductions and strategies.
